team which is so much more important that people realize.

comments.text:
The argument between Fergie and Pogba was ridiculous. You've heard him say 
it a billion times. No man is bigger than the club. Fans like yourself may 
still cry over the Pogba deal, trust me you're not the only one mate. I've 
been hearing united fans bitching about it for years. But if an 18 yr old 
has the testicles to go up to Alex Ferguson and say I want to be given 
40,000 a week and be played more regularly or i'm going to leave then OF 
COURSE he was going to be let go. There's no respect in football anymore. 
His lack of humility puts him in the same category as players like Tevez, 
Heinze, Morrison and even Rooney. Only difference is that Moyes is letting 
Rooney bend him over a table whereas Fergie would have let him go. Players 
like that don't leave for football reasons. They leave because the club are 
perfectly capable of winning titles without those parasites. As we proved 
last year. Maybe one day our own fans will realise this. Doubtful though.
comments.author: Gregory Boatswain

comments.text:
+Darkus Diezel No Ferguson won titles with average players, besides

results went his way.  Look at the two now, what are they doing now?  Pogba 
will get a Scudetto in Italy.

comments.text:
Welbeck has more than earned his place for England.  More than anything he 
is the only English player with the balls to actually score goals now that 
Defoe has retired. Rooney however, he's been awful for England but keeps 
getting picked based on club form.  He simply doesn't have the mentality to 
play tournament football. Often I watch matches and Gerrard seems to have 
to do everything whilst the rest just stand around statically accepting 
simple passes.  Welbeck is the only one that realises goals win games.

Watch the Denmark game for example.  Before Welbeck we had about 2 shots, 
within 10 minutes of being on the pitch Welbeck had made 3 or 4 chances.  I 
don't even care if he couldn't hit a barn door, as long as he's in there he 
is causing problems that Rooney and others simply don't.
comments.author: AWellTimedCupOfTea

comments.text:

comments.author: Dan G

comments.text:
+얄청림 You may be right on that, but they have loads of players with enough 
talent to play around him. Arguably a lot of talent. In fact they have a 
handful of players that are a step or two away from world class. Plus the 
93' class has massive potential as well does the next era of English 
players.

Almost any team in the world would kill to have that kind of setup.

The team overall are solid defensively and are tough to score on. They 
force the opposition to beat them instead of beating themselves. We saw 
that in Euro 2012 with France, Ukraine, and Italy (They beat themselves 
against Sweden, but still won). Also they only conceded 4 goals in 
qualifying which was 3rd best in Europe.

You seem to judge England on results. They beat Brazil a year ago 2-1 and 
then tied them in Rio 2-2. They also have just about every team they play 
against relishing to beat them. Chile beat England 2-0, who brought over a 
full squad and not taking it lightly at all. Plus England were 
experimenting and didn't have their normal setup. That is when they didn't 
have a full squad, yet they even had the lead near the end. When England 
have a full squad (almost or everybody available), which is rare, they are 
not only tough to beat, but dangerous. Montenegro and Poland found that 
out. They had a killer instinct type approach.

England are not as bad you rate them to be at. I have made that error a lot 
on other teams too.
comments.author: John Hough

england that is capable to face those teams

comments.text:

hard. Montenegro, Poland, and Ukraine are no teams to ease off on.

Ireland and Scotland are average at best, but play England like its a World 
Cup game because they hate England so much. Ever heard of rivalries? 
Scotland and Ireland send out their best possible squads to play against an 
average England squad. Watch the matches.

You can't just rate a team by watching a couple of matches. Heck if you 
only saw England play Montenegro and Poland in October you would think 
England are very good.

captions.text: I was lucky enough all my mates on the street all love football.
We didn’t really play computer games. We just stayed out until it got dark.
Just trying to find the top corner in the back garden.
I just love football.
Even if I didn’t play it I’d probably be still in the stands.
I’ve been there as a fan.
It’s frustrating when you can’t do anything about it
but I’m one of the lucky ones who can actually do something about it on the pitch.
Growing up you watch all your idols and they’re playing for their country
and obviously that’s something you really want to do yourself.
Once you’re out there on the pitch you still are that little boy inside.
I first started playing with Clevs, I think I was 12 years old.
Clevs was one of my best mates then and he is still now.
If you play for the 16s, 17s, 18s, 19s, 21s and then the senior squad it just feels like a natural progression.
I think it’s a good place for us St George’s and it feels a lot more like a club.
The under 21s are there, the under 19s.
The younger players in the squad have got older players to look up to thinking we want to have their careers, we want to win their medals.
You’re always looking for that next step. Even now, last season was a big one for me, I got 9 caps.
Then you see people like Ash winning their 100th cap.
One day you want to be like them.
It makes you just want more and hopefully one day I’ll have numerous caps and titles
and young players will be saying I hope I have that career.
If he’s not playing, he’s watching from the side and we’ve got to the level where
I can ask Welbs what do you feel I can do more in this game, and vice-versa.
So we help each other that way and when we’re both on the pitch we seem to know what each other want.
I know the movement he makes, he knows the passes I make.
So it’s good to have a familiar face on the pitch with me.
It was very frustrating to go to Brazil and not being able to take part.
But it was good to go out there, obviously to travel with the squad.
You’re getting valuable experience actually going out there and doing it.
So I had to look at it in a positive way and that’s the way I took it.
We need to qualify first but when we get there I can go to Brazil and say
I’ve been here before.
This season’s massive for me and I really want to try and cement my place
and score a lot more goals and try and get some trophies under my belt as well.
We’ve got four massive games in the next two months so the squad definitely needs this friendly.
Even though it’s probably not going to be a friendly, it’s a game that we all really want to win
for us, for the fans, to have good confidence. And I think even more important for me and Welbs.
We’ve not played for England since March so we definitely need this August friendly.
Wembley stadium, ready and raucous. Not a night for neutrals.
It’s always a brilliant feeling when you get told you’re starting for England.
I knew it was a bit more than a friendly and it had that feel as soon as we got to the ground.
Supported by Tom Cleverley.
Welbeck…
Hooked on by Cleverley.
It’s a great ball.
Walcott checks…
And scores!
You always think about passes like that in your head.
Things like that can start before the game even happens.
You realise that Theo’s pace is an area where we can beat teams.
I just checked to make sure Theo was going and played the ball first time.
I’m always buzzing when we score.
But when it’s Welbs, my mate outside of football, some people don’t really see what job he does for the team.
And as a player you can see that first hand.
I think when we got the free-kick I just tried to get myself into a dangerous position,
into that special place, and I got there.
Clevs was the first person to celebrate with me and I was buzzing.
It was the equaliser and we just knew we needed to get the winner.
Thankfully Rickie Lambert did that.
Dream debut!
We’ve got a lot of technical players now. People like Jack Wilshere and Ox.
I think the future looks bright for England.
And hopefully we can have success at tournaments.
You can always keep on improving.
Keep on going every single day.
Once I retire I just hope that I’ve served my country well.
And I’ve played some very important games.
And I want to go to a major and obviously try and win a trophy as well.
I honestly couldn’t picture myself doing anything else except playing football.

title: England Matters - Episode 2: Tom Cleverley & Danny Welbeck
